0.doc: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special
0.title: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special
0.content: . | The Significance of Strong Passwords | NIST‚Äôs Password Guidelines for Consumers . | 1. Passphrases Over Passwords | 2. Longer is Better | 3. Avoid Common Words and Patterns | 4. Regular Password Updates | 5. Embrace Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) | . | Why is NIST guidance relevant to me? . | 1. Expertise and Credibility | 2. Real-World Testing | 3. Ongoing Updates | 4. Wide Applicability | 5. Personal Cyber Resilience | . | Conclusion | . In a digital landscape filled with potential threats, your online security hinges on the strength of your passwords. October is Cybersecurity Awareness Month, making it the perfect time to revisit your password practices and bolster your digital defences. The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), a renowned authority in cybersecurity, offers a comprehensive framework for password security that is pivotal for safeguarding both organisational data and your personal online presence.

1.doc: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special
1.title: The Significance of Strong Passwords
1.content: Before we delve into the specifics of NIST‚Äôs guidelines, let‚Äôs underline the crucial role strong passwords play in the realm of cybersecurity. Passwords are your initial line of defence against unauthorised access to your accounts, personal information, and sensitive data. Weak passwords are like open doors inviting cybercriminals in, while strong passwords act as the locks that keep them out.

2.doc: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special
2.title: NIST‚Äôs Password Guidelines for Consumers
2.content: NIST‚Äôs Special Publication 800-63B, known as the ‚ÄúDigital Identity Guidelines,‚Äù furnishes a robust set of recommendations for creating and maintaining secure passwords. Here‚Äôs how you can implement these guidelines to fortify your personal online security: . 1. Passphrases Over Passwords . NIST emphasises the use of passphrases over conventional passwords. Passphrases, composed of multiple words or a sentence, are longer and easier to remember. For instance, ‚ÄúCoffeeLover$MakeGreatMornings!‚Äù is a strong passphrase that is not only secure but also user-friendly. 2. Longer is Better . NIST suggests a minimum password length of 12 characters. Longer passwords offer enhanced security, as they present a more formidable challenge to attackers attempting to crack them. To boost complexity, incorporate a mix of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. The concept a passphrase comes into its own when combined with this suggestion. Using your favourite sentence from a book can be a great start to a strong password. 3. Avoid Common Words and Patterns . Steer clear of easily guessable passwords. NIST recommends avoiding common words, phrases, and patterns like ‚Äú123456,‚Äù ‚Äúpassword,‚Äù or ‚Äúqwerty,‚Äù as they are susceptible to dictionary attacks. This advice from NIST also applies to things like your company name, birthday, names of family members etc. 4. Regular Password Updates . NIST no longer endorses frequent password changes, which can lead to weaker passwords due to predictable patterns (e.g., ‚Äúpassword1,‚Äù ‚Äúpassword2,‚Äù and so on). Instead, change your password only when there is a known compromise or if you suspect unauthorised access. While I admit, this is the most contentious piece of advice in this article, I stand by it. If you have a sufficiently long and complex password, there is no requirement to change the password. Password strength checkers estimate the above password ‚ÄúCoffeeLover$MakeGreatMornings!‚Äù would take 13 centuries to crack. A string of 19 random characters with a mix of lower case, upper case, numbers and symbols would take 2 thousand trillion years. Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, and Mozilla Firefox all have functionality built into their password managers to alert you to compromised passwords, as do the major password managers on the market. 5. Embrace Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) . Implementing MFA is strongly encouraged. It adds an additional layer of security by requiring something you know (your password) and something you have (e.g., a mobile app or a hardware token) to access your accounts. Most major services will offer some form of MFA for accounts. And if they don‚Äôt, you should strongly consider whether you need to use the service and what kind of data of yours they are storing.

3.doc: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special
3.title: Why is NIST guidance relevant to me?
3.content: NIST‚Äôs password security guidelines hold crucial significance, not only for organisations, but also for individual consumers, for several compelling reasons: . 1. Expertise and Credibility . NIST is a highly respected and authoritative institution in the realm of technology and cybersecurity. Their recommendations are developed by experts who continuously analyse and adapt to the ever-evolving threat landscape. 2. Real-World Testing . NIST‚Äôs guidelines are grounded in real-world security testing and research, stemming from a profound understanding of how cyberattacks occur and how to effectively counter them. 3. Ongoing Updates . NIST‚Äôs willingness to adapt its guidelines to changing circumstances ensures that their recommendations remain pertinent and effective in the face of emerging threats. 4. Wide Applicability . NIST guidelines aren‚Äôt just reserved for government agencies; they are widely used by organisations and individuals around the world. This broad acceptance underscores their practicality and effectiveness. 5. Personal Cyber Resilience . By adhering to NIST‚Äôs recommendations, you can significantly bolster your personal cybersecurity stance and enhance your resilience against emerging threats. NIST‚Äôs focus on secure, user-friendly practices, such as using passphrases and implementing MFA, positions it as a valuable benchmark for achieving cyber resilience as a consumer.

4.doc: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special
4.title: Conclusion
4.content: In conclusion, NIST‚Äôs recommendations for password security provide a robust framework to strengthen your personal defences against the ever-evolving digital threat landscape. By adopting the latest guidance outlined in the Special Publication 800-63B, you can fortify your digital identity and maintain cyber resilience. Remember, your password is your first line of defence and NIST‚Äôs guidelines set the standard for building a secure fortress in the digital age. If you are concerned about creating complex passwords you can remember even with the above advice, you may want to look into passwords managers. They all come with various security features and at different price points, but you are guaranteed to find one that meets your needs.

5.doc: Elevate Your Password Security: A Cybersecurity Awareness Month Special

6.doc: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
6.title: üê† Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
6.content: Welcome to the reef. It‚Äôs bright, busy, and occasionally bites. If you‚Äôve ever looked at Microsoft‚Äôs cloud security stack and felt overwhelmed‚Äîrelax. You don‚Äôt need a million certs, a rack of gear, or clearance from ASIO. What you do need are a few essential tools, a healthy dose of curiosity, and the philosophical fortitude of one very strange animal. Let‚Äôs begin.

7.doc: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
7.title: üß∞ 1. A Laptop (Not Fancy, Just Functional)
7.content: You don‚Äôt need a 96-core monster with RGB lighting and a GPU capable of rendering Middle-earth. A solid laptop with a modern browser, a decent CPU, and a willingness to multitask is more than enough.

8.doc: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
8.title: üìö 2. Documentation (The Microsoft Kind)
8.content: Your new best friend is the Microsoft Learn platform. Bookmark the docs for Defender for Cloud, Entra ID, Intune, and the Security Compliance toolkit.

9.doc: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
9.title: üíª 3. VS Code (or Something Equally Sassy)
9.content: You‚Äôll be scripting policies, writing JSON, and poking Graph API with a stick. Visual Studio Code is your lightweight Swiss Army knife. Install extensions for: . | Azure Resource Manager (ARM) | Bicep | PowerShell | Markdown | . Bonus: add GitHub integration.

10.doc: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
10.title: ü¶Ü 4. An Insatiable Need to Know (Activate Your Inner Platypus)
10.content: You‚Äôll need one key trait to thrive in Microsoft Cloud Security: curiosity. Channel your inner platypus‚Äîa creature that lays eggs, senses electromagnetic fields, and has venom. It‚Äôs weird, underestimated, and perfectly adapted to thrive where few others can. So should you be. üêô Coming Up Next in Snorkelling: . | ‚ÄúThe Portal Tour: What the Hell is Where?‚Äù | ‚ÄúM365 vs Azure Security: Why Are There Two of Everything?‚Äù | ‚ÄúConditional Access for Humans (Not Robots)‚Äù | . Until then, snorkel up, curiosity on. The reef‚Äôs only going to get weirder from here.

11.doc: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security
11.title: Snorkelling: Getting Started with Microsoft Cloud Security

12.doc: Leadership Isn't Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It's Just Good Process
12.title: Leadership Isn‚Äôt Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It‚Äôs Just Good Process
12.content: By Someone Who‚Äôs Not Here to Sell You Positivity Kool-Aid . | Leadership, Without the Pom-Poms | Most IT Projects Are Simple ‚Äî If You Manage the Process | The Velvet Hammer Approach | . When people talk about ‚Äúleadership‚Äù in tech (and especially in IT project work), the conversation often splits into two camps. There‚Äôs the Chipper Brigade: . | Always smiling | Always upbeat | Always talking about ‚Äúsynergy‚Äù and ‚Äútransformational journeys‚Äù | Probably has a spreadsheet color-coded by the phases of the moon | . And then there‚Äôs people like me: . | Direct, measured | Focused on the outcome, not the parade | Calmly skeptical because, well, we‚Äôve seen things | More ‚Äúlet‚Äôs execute well‚Äù than ‚Äúlet‚Äôs all feel amazing while burning down scope‚Äù | . Here‚Äôs the truth: both approaches can work. But one of them tends to survive real-world IT projects with fewer therapy bills.

13.doc: Leadership Isn't Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It's Just Good Process
13.title: Leadership, Without the Pom-Poms
13.content: Thanks to a slightly unusual combination of strengths (Gallup‚Äôs Deliberative, Responsibility, Relator, Analytical, Learner, and a healthy dash of Command), and a neurodivergent brain wired for pattern detection, I approach leadership a little differently: . | I don‚Äôt pretend problems aren‚Äôt there. Leadership isn‚Äôt about ignoring risk. It‚Äôs about managing it deliberately, responsibly, with eyes wide open. | I don‚Äôt need everyone to ‚Äúfeel amazing‚Äù all the time. I need everyone to know what their job is, have the support to do it, and be able to escalate real issues without fear of being told to ‚Äújust stay positive.‚Äù . | I‚Äôm not obsessed with being the loudest voice in the room. I‚Äôm obsessed with the signal-to-noise ratio. Good leadership is making sure communication cuts through cleanly, not making everyone louder. | . In short, I‚Äôm not the glass-half-full leader, nor the glass-half-empty one. I‚Äôm the ‚Äúwho‚Äôs in charge of topping up the glass?‚Äù leader. It‚Äôs the difference between optimism and operational reality.

14.doc: Leadership Isn't Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It's Just Good Process
14.title: Most IT Projects Are Simple ‚Äî If You Manage the Process
14.content: Here‚Äôs the dirty little secret of most IT projects, especially in cloud and security: . | The technology is not the hard part. Vendors (and engineers) like to act like it is because it makes them feel important, but if you can read and click a mouse, most modern platforms are straightforward (after the 15th acronym, anyway). | Managing change is the hard part. People. Expectations. Timelines. The process around change. Communication. Handling resistance without letting it fester into sabotage. That‚Äôs where projects live or die. | Communication is not the same as cheerleading. Communication is making sure people know what‚Äôs happening, when, why it matters to them, and what to expect next. It‚Äôs setting clear expectations, not inflating them with empty positivity. | . So when I ‚Äúlead,‚Äù it‚Äôs not with relentless smiles or rah-rah speeches. It‚Äôs with deliberate planning, direct communication, and ruthless clarity on what matters. That‚Äôs what builds trust. That‚Äôs what drives outcomes. That‚Äôs what gets projects done.

15.doc: Leadership Isn't Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It's Just Good Process
15.title: The Velvet Hammer Approach
15.content: I‚Äôve been described as a ‚Äúvelvet hammer‚Äù ‚Äî direct but not cruel, firm but fair, outcomes-focused without trampling people. That‚Äôs leadership too. It just looks less like a TED talk and more like an architect quietly pointing out where the foundation needs to be reinforced before the house collapses. And honestly? . In IT (and especially in security), I‚Äôd rather be the architect than the hype man.

16.doc: Leadership Isn't Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It's Just Good Process
16.title: Leadership Isn't Always a Pep Rally: Sometimes It's Just Good Process

17.doc: Transitioning from System Engineer to IT Consultant: Leveraging Your Existing Skills
17.title: Transitioning from System Engineer to IT Consultant: Leveraging Your Existing Skills
17.content: Are you a seasoned systems engineer looking to make the leap into the world of IT consulting? Are you worried that you are too much of a generalist to become a specialist? It can be a daunting prospect, but know that it can also be a rewarding transition. You can leverage your existing skills and propel your career to new heights. We will explore five key themes that I came across while making the transition. 1. Trust Your Technology Skills . As a system engineer, you‚Äôve spent years in the trenches mastering various technologies, troubleshooting complex issues, and architecting solutions. Don‚Äôt underestimate the value of your technical expertise. In the world of IT consulting, clients seek professionals who can provide expert guidance on technology-related matters. Your broad and deep knowledge in this area is a valuable asset that will set you apart from the competition. If you have kept your skills up to date to support your employer you can keep up to date with the latest industry trends and advancements to support your future customers. 2. Focus on Business Skills, Including Presentations . While your technical skills are essential a successful IT consultant also possesses strong business acumen. Learning to speak the language of your clients is essential, whether that is honing your communication, negotiation or project management skills. Effective presentation skills are also particularly crucial as they enable you to clearly convey complex technical information to non-technical stakeholders. You should invest time in improving your ability to articulate your ideas, proposals and solutions. 3. Expectation Management . In the consulting world, managing expectations is paramount. You have to be transparent and realistic when discussion project timelines, deliverables and potential challenges with clients. Making sure you set accurate expectations from the beginning will help to build trust and prevent misunderstandings down the road. Effective expectation management is a key element of successful client relationships. This may seem daunting, but you have likely been doing this for internal projects already. 4. Understand the ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù . Being a good IT consultant must go beyond the technical problem-solving. You need to take the time to understand the underlying business goals and objectives your client is trying to meet. Your technical solution should align with their strategic vision. If you can move beyond problem-solving and also help the client meet their business objectives, you become a trusted partner rather than just a service provider. 5. Realize You‚Äôve Already Been Consulting . While you have likely never officially held the title of ‚Äúconsultant,‚Äù if you are employed as a systems engineer, you‚Äôve most likely provided consulting-like services to internal teams or clients. Reflect on your past experiences where you have offered guidance, made recommendations for solutions, or helped others to solve a problem. These instances all demonstrate the same abilities that consultants use, even if it was informal. Recognizing your existing experience in consulting can boost your confidence when you make the transition. It definitely helped me! . Conclusion . Transitioning from a systems engineer to an IT consultant is an exciting journey that allows you to leverage your existing skills while greatly expanding your horizons. Trust in your technical expertise, continue to develop your business skills, master expectation management, understand the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind the solution, and realize you‚Äôve already been consulting. With the five key themes in mind, embrace your new role as an IT consultant with confidence and enthusiasm. Your own unique combination of technical skills and consulting mindset will undoubtedly lead to a successful and fulfilling career in IT consulting. If this sounds like something that interests you maybe you would like to Join The Crew - Arinco .

18.doc: Transitioning from System Engineer to IT Consultant: Leveraging Your Existing Skills
18.title: Transitioning from System Engineer to IT Consultant: Leveraging Your Existing Skills

19.title: The Cuttlefish
19.content: . By now, you‚Äôre probably wondering why I chose a cuttlefish as our guide on this cybersecurity journey. If you‚Äôre not, then this whole paragraph has no point, and that would be a shame.‚Äã . I initially considered a raccoon‚Äîyou know, looks permanently exhausted, always has its hands full, and there‚Äôs a non-zero chance it might bite you!‚Äã . But I realized that the cuttlefish better embodies the modern cybersecurity team. They don‚Äôt rely on brute force or thick armor like a saltie; they survive through intelligence and the ability to adapt to any situation‚Ä¶ and they‚Äôre kind of clever. Sound familiar?‚Äã . Yes‚Ä¶ you just got compared to a cephalopod! In a good way, I promise‚Ä¶‚Äã .

20.title: What makes me tick?
20.content: I‚Äôve got my tentacles dipped into several digital ponds:‚Äã . | I wrestle with Microsoft Azure until it behaves. | I fortify Microsoft 365 environments (but still keep them usable). | I make sense (or try to) of cybersecurity frameworks and eliminate the headaches. | I build cloud security solutions that work in the real world, not just the ivory tower. | .

21.title: Why am I writing
21.content: Honestly, we‚Äôve all endured those mind-numbing presentations where we have no idea what‚Äôs being discussed. It‚Äôs acronym soup with a side of jargon, and at this point, you‚Äôre not even sure they‚Äôre speaking English.‚Äã . I know there‚Äôs a better way.‚Äã . Security doesn‚Äôt have to be scary, cloud computing doesn‚Äôt have to be cloudy (hmmm ‚Äì I‚Äôll work on that), and frameworks don‚Äôt need to be oppressive.‚Äã . I want cybersecurity to be accessible to anyone who works with technology. My pet peeve is when people say, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not my job‚Äù or ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt understand.‚Äù I‚Äôm making it my mission to make cybersecurity more accessible.‚Äã .

22.title: What you can expect here
22.content: This blog will strive to cut through the noise. We‚Äôre not playing buzzword bingo, and we won‚Äôt participate in fear-mongering.‚Äã . What we will do is:‚Äã . | Provide practical security advice from the Mariana (mmmm Marinara) trenches. | Share the adventures and misadventures of cybersecurity. | Break down cybersecurity frameworks in a way that actually makes sense. | Tackle cloud conundrums and their solutions without the wet blanket. | Include lots of terrible puns and animal references that will (hopefully) make sense to you as well | .

23.title: Pull up a chair
23.content: Whether you‚Äôre a hardened security veteran, curious about what makes the cloud tick, or even if you work in sales (I won‚Äôt judge), you‚Äôre welcome here. We‚Äôll explore together, share some laughs, and try to find better ways to do this.‚Äã . I‚Äôm just going to duck off and make a coffee (my favorite is ‚ÄúLots‚Äù), and then we can dive in and explore cybersecurity with less doom and gloom and more ‚ÄúAh, I get it now!‚Äù‚Äã .

24.title: About
24.content: What‚Äôs up? Looks at the sky - yeah I know‚Ä¶its a bad joke- you‚Äôll get used to it‚Ä¶ . If we haven‚Äôt met before, my name is Scott. I‚Äôm a recovering Systems Engineer turned Cloud Architect, working for a leading Microsoft Partner in Sydney. I spend my (work) days adapting to and navigating the shifting currents of cloud security.‚Äã .

27.title: Contact Me
27.content: I‚Äôd love to hear from you! Feel free to reach out via email or social media. | Email: scott@parrybytes.cloud | GitHub: scottjparry | LinkedIn: scottjparry | .

29.title: üêô Welcome to ParryBytes.cloud
29.content: Cybersecurity, with less doom and gloom and more ‚ÄúAh, I get it now!‚Äù . Dive into a space where cloud security meets clarity. At ParryBytes.cloud, we explore the depths of cybersecurity, making complex concepts accessible and engaging.

30.title: üåä Explore Our Depths
30.content: Echoes from the Deep: Strategic insights and overarching trends in cloud security. Snorkelling: Practical, real-world guidance and applied case studies. Deep Dives: In-depth technical explorations and detailed analyses. Dive Buddies: Discussions on leadership, team dynamics, and non-technical aspects. Echoes from Elsewhere: Republished professional blogs from my employer, shared with permission.

31.title: üß† About Me
31.content: I‚Äôm a Cloud Security Architect based in Australia, specializing in governance, risk, and compliance. My passion lies in security frameworks and Identity and Access Management. With experience spanning national and international businesses, I aim to bridge the gap between complex security concepts and practical implementation.

32.title: üì¨ Stay Connected
32.content: Have questions or want to collaborate? Reach out via contact . | Email: scott@parrybytes.cloud | GitHub: scottjparry | LinkedIn: scottjparry | .

33.title: Why the animal theme?
33.content: I chose animal themes‚Äîparticularly oceanic ones like the cuttlefish‚Äîbecause they reflect the nature of cybersecurity work: adaptive, intelligent, and often operating in the unseen depths. The ocean is vast and complex, just like the cloud. Plus, let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîsecurity blogs are more fun with tentacles.

34.title: üåÄ Echoes from Elsewhere
34.content: Thoughts that began in other currents. Content originally written for the day job or external engagements, shared here with context and colour. Sometimes edited, sometimes annotated, always aligned to the ParryBytes voice. If it‚Äôs here, it‚Äôs worth the rerun.

36.title: ü§ø Dive Buddies
36.content: Reflections with your fins-on-the-ground crew. This is where we surface from the tech for a bit. Expect posts about working in security teams, leading without managing, navigating neurodiversity in consulting, and finding your rhythm in high-performance environments. Less configs, more conversations.

37.title: üê† Snorkelling
37.content: Exploring the reef, just below the surface. These posts skim across a variety of security topics‚Äîenough depth to inform and intrigue, but without needing to decompress afterward. Think overviews, how-tos, quick wins, and curated explorations that let you see the colourful coral of cloud security without strapping on full SCUBA gear.

38.title: üß† Deep Dives
38.content: Tentacle-level technical analysis. For those who like getting elbow-deep in policy settings, identity flows, and security configurations. These are unapologetically detailed posts built for practitioners‚Äîthink of them as the decompression chamber for engineers who want substance over fluff.

39.title: üåä Echoes from the Deep
39.content: Where the tide turns in strategy and insight. These posts dive into the broader ocean currents shaping cloud security‚Äîfrom evolving threat landscapes to governance frameworks, digital trust, and executive-aligned decision-making. If you‚Äôre after the ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs coming next?‚Äù or need to frame your security uplift in a boardroom-friendly way, this is your sonar.

42.content: This post discusses a velvet-hammer approach to cybersecurity‚Ä¶ .
